title: The white feminism of western media
description:
‚ú®Get Nebula using my link for 40% off an annual subscription: https://go.nebula.tv/alicecappelle
Watch Tom Nicholas' Boomers: https://go.nebula.tv/tomnicholas?ref=alicecappelle

Bonjour ! This video is about the representation of arab/brown/muslim women in Western media. I very much welcome your feedback on this on, it's definitely a sensitive topic and the term islamophobia is only starting to gain recognition. This video basically looks at the special status arab/muslim/brown women receive in the media and how it's affecting their lives in the West and in the Middle East, especially in Palestine.


SOURCES/RESSOURCES üìö

Journalists/researchers: Zahra Hankir (Our Women on the Ground), Hannah Allam, Nour Malas, Hwaida Saad, Lina AbiRafeh, Sherine Tadros (really liked her memoir Taking Sides), Louisa Yousfi (in defense of barbarism), Shahrzad Mojab

Writers: Jokha Alharthi, Sahar Khalifeh

Content creators: Amani Al‚ÄëKhatahtbeh (MuslimGirl.net) , Nedal Reads (instagram), Bisan Owda, Plestia Alaqad

The starter pack of middle eastern feminism: Routledge handbook on Women in the Middle East

Essays and manifesto:
Sarah Farris, In the Name of Women‚Äôs Rights
Fran√ßoise Verg√®s, Decolonial Feminism
Cinzia Arruzza,¬†Tithi Bhattacharya¬†and¬†Nancy Fraser, Feminism for the 99%

title: VLOG make a video essay w/ me üë©‚Äçüíªüìö
description:
Sign up for Notion here: https://ntn.so/alice
Please use this link so that they know I sent you to their website merciii :)

Bonjour !

‚ú®Support the channel on Patreon and get to join our discord chat room: https://www.patreon.com/alicecappelle

Extra writing tips that I couldn't fit into the video:
- I find it's always better to start an essay/ a chapter with an anecdote or something people can easily relate to. It's a pattern you'll find in most non-fiction books. In my master's thesis (social history), I would start every chapter with a little historical anecdote or focus on one person's daily activities, switching from the micro and the macro really makes the essay coherent and engaging. 
-I'll say it again but structure/narrative is everything. Reading a good essay should feel like someone is holding your hand from start to finish. What I think is challenging is to find a balance between being technical, making complex points and remaining accessible and fun/not condescending. That's why we all love Contrapoints. 
-Don't just read for information. Pay attention at the way the essayist, author articulates ideas. Get used to recognize the rhetorical tools mobilized, how ideas are structured, how people write in your field of study. Copy the masters and add your own twist to it :)
-In video essays (it's not very common in traditional essays), I find that open questions can be useful both as transitions (end part 1 with question, suspens, answer in beginning of part 2) but also as a way to subtly share your opinion or nuance the opinion of others.
